head.title: In the Street, Among the Masses

hedline.hl1: In the Street, Among the Masses

abstract.p: J C Dwyer and Lara Cassell letters on David Margolick's April 15 New York Observed essay on seeing familiar faces during certain seasons in New York City

block.p: ''Familiar Faces in the Crowd, and Why They're Rare,'' by David Margolick (New York Observed, April 15), was absurd. For one thing, he asserts that ''much of New York is out of town'' June through August. Not to denigrate the migratory patterns of the super-rich, but most of New York stays right here in the summer.

''Familiar Faces in the Crowd, and Why They're Rare,'' by David Margolick (New York Observed, April 15), was absurd. For one thing, he asserts that ''much of New York is out of town'' June through August. Not to denigrate the migratory patterns of the super-rich, but most of New York stays right here in the summer.
I see people I know surprisingly often, for good statistical reason: we tend to haunt the same neighborhoods.
J. C. Dwyer Park Slope, Brooklyn

Thank you to David Margolick for his all-too-true portrayal of street encounters. As a displaced New Yorker, I fiercely miss my days of anonymity in the big city, and the privilege of walking without being force-fed a hello from every passer-by.
Merely 10 minutes ago, a stranger remarked, ''Excuse me, miss, you seemed to have dropped your smile'' as I walked our main street. I labored to suppress a growl.
Thanks for giving a homesick gal a little piece of her much-missed New York.
